I had not previously realised that this was a hotly debated subject, but I =
can think of at least one example of a test that should have at least two a=
ssertion in it: the equals() method.

According to the Java API, an .equals=
() method must be symmetric, so for a.equals(b) to be true, then b.equals(a=
) must also be true. This seems like something that would justify two asser=
ts within a test.

Also, what about edge-conditions? If a method has a numb=
er of interesting edge-conditions, then do each of those go in separate tes=
ts?

Simon
